subsection_content:
1. Clinical
When diagnosing pyelonephritis, the doctor will rely on symptoms such as:
Symptoms of infection: Chills, high fever, fatigue, headache, dirty tongue, dry lips...; Symptoms of acute bladder: Dysuria, painful urination, frequent urination, hematuria, cloudy urine, pus.; Symptoms of pain: Severe pain in the back and flanks, usually on one side, rarely on both sides. There are cases where renal colic occurs.
2. Paraclinical
Blood count test: Acute pyelonephritis is an infection. Therefore, doctors often prescribe patients to have a blood test to check for a clearly increased white blood cell index, especially neutrophil increase; Blood culture: This method helps determine which group of bacteria the urinary tract infection is caused by.; Ultrasound: look for signs of ureteral dilatation,  renal pelvis dilatation, images of kidney and urinary stones, tumor compression...; X-ray:  when vesicoureteral reflux is suspected.
In addition, to determine pyelonephritis, additional tests can be performed such as proteinuria, Addis sediment, and urine culture for bacteria. This will help the doctor determine the diagnosis, thereby providing treatment for the patient.
